Sotnikova did not have a flawless program…she stepped out of the landing on the last jump of a combination.

My husband, who's a much more casual fan than me, & I were discussing the results afterwards. He said that he hadn't seen a single performance in either the men's or women's competition that he would have classified as "perfect." My take was that there were only two programs that I'd like to watch again…Kim's SP & Jason Brown's LP (& I'd prefer to watch his performance from the US Nationals). Years ago I'd watch programs over & over again because they were artistically interesting, well skated, & technically demanding. People may argue that today's programs are more technically demanding, but I disagree…the only aspect in which they're more technically demanding are in the jumps. The spins, footwork, step sequences, etc., were almost all uniformly performed at a higher level in years past. When that's coupled w/jumps that are almost as technically demanding as today's—& landed successfully w/more regularity—skating's a lot more rewarding to watch.

and has left trillions of GDP on the table - or under the bridge as Paul Krugman writes.

Rosy predictions are a shortcoming of Obama's administration and have served as easy targets upon which the GOP can pounce. But derision isn't growth. Growth requires demand, spending. Milton Friedman and Marx both agreed on this. The modern GOP doesn't. It's political economy is based on returns before the fact of demand increasing. They ignore that spending reflects demand.

Ignored, too, is the fact that an economy as large as the US can rarely grow faster than the global aggregate. Just as interest rates are constrained by the zero lower bound, the US macro economy is limited by domestic and international demand, and with China slowing and Europe experiencing stagnant employment and a double dip recession with slow growth even now, demand was not supported or created at home or aboard.

The GOP isolation of the economy, except for borrowing (overtly ascribed to China, another cliché!) is a political distortion, whose purpose is blame not to produce sound policy.

Actually, the US led the global recovery, not lagged behind it; another measure that the GOP claims of fault are not true.

Ask Republicans when the bubbles burst, where does demand come from? Increase demand. There you will find jobs. It's hard, as Rep. Jim Clyburn said, to gave a person a tax cut who does have one. And, as Paul says, look at Europe; austerity doesn't bring prosperity out of a recession. The GOP idea is economic alchemy that doesn't work--and leaves American workers out of work!

Cooks, all I heard for years before the ACA was "my insurance costs are going up 20% again". I am a lucky dog. I actually am a federal employee retiree with the old CS pension and insurance. I didn't realize how rare a pension and retirement insurance was until 10-15 yrs ago. My retired at 50 or so cop brother-in-law never pays a nickel for any medical cost although his cop union forgot about spouses in that. I still pay 25-30% of all costs. I remember when insurance and providers were not very expensive before I started working for the big bad gov in 72 part time. Didn't get the ins till 76. My daughter was born in 74 and total cost was a whopping $500. And docs would accept payment of $10/mo with no complaint. Gas was 50 cents. Yup prices have gone up, but how much have working peoples wages gone up to match?

By the way federal employees have never had a union with any clout and since 84 or 86 new hires all pay full SS with an extra 401k plan.

Let me be one to disagree. Rules are often arbitrary. The rules of chess are arbitrary. "Queen on color" so the black queen on black square, white queen on white square.

What if I want to play with both queens on white squares, or follow the convention "king on color"?

The answer is that then I am not playing chess. If I belong to a chess club, and insist on this kind of positioning, then either no one will play with me or I may be asked to leave the club. Joining the club is voluntary. But if I do join the club, then obeying the rules is compulsory.

They know they'll get paid.  Insurance does cost her around $500/mo and drugs cost another $500.  Half of her SS and teacher pension.  But she has no problem at all getting into a provider.  Guess Kansas is different.  We live in a town of 80k with two big hospitals and doctors all over.  Course western MT might be a more desirable place to live than KS. allan,It is a fact that J.K. Rowling wrote the Harry Potter novels while she was on the dole, and wrote about that fact herself. The question was not whether or not the freedom to be choosier about jobs is going to make everybody super successful. The question is whether or not giving people a cushion of safety has benefits that can outweigh losses. For example, in the old days, kids might have to forgo college in order to help support their families if their parents fell on hard times. Do you think that was better for their bottom line? The children of middle and upper class families are routinely shielded from the need to take any and every job that comes their way, and, on the whole, they seem to do quite well for themselves.

I would argue that you are certainly making a political point by choosing to view an 84 acre former army base with less than 1000 residents, many of whom were committed to living highly unstructured lives, as an example of the failure of a social safety net. I suggest that if you look at Kibbutzim in Israel, for example, you might find a considerable number of artists and authors who reside in them. And in fact, the Kibbutzim were traditionally known as a source of top military officers in the army, which I believe went along with the ethos of doing one's part for society. In fact, I believe in most militaries, the ethos is very much one of being part of a larger group. Maybe Christiania has a surfeit of individualism.
